page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF UPPER WEARDALE
page.content: In its upper reaches the{River Wear}is fast flowing and narrow with pictur- esque waterfalls at West Blackdene and Middle Blackdene. As it flows down the valley it is joined by the{Ireshope {Burn,}the{Cleugh Burn}and various {sikes}(narrow rivulets that drain the hillsides). The valley floor is narrow and winding and the fields, enclosed by{dry stone walls,}rise up on either side to meet the moorland. Trees grow fairly thickly by the river and burn sides but, apart from two conifer plantations, the upper slopes are bare of trees. There are no village greens, the villages having grown up on either side of the main road. Houses are mostly of stone, some still retaining the old{stone slab roofs, some roofed with slate or, more recently, pre-fabricated tiles.
